item.name: Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.title: Expressing support for designation of Saint Louis, Missouri, as the "National Chess Capital" to enhance awareness of the educational benefits of chess and to encourage schools and community centers to engage in chess programs to promote problem solving, critical thinking, spatial awareness, and goal setting.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

item.name: Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee
Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions Committee

item.text: Referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions. (text of measure as introduced: CR S2805)

summary.text:
Expresses support for the designation of Saint Louis, Missouri, as the "National Chess Capital" of the United States.

Encourages the people of Saint Louis to continue promoting the educational benefits of chess among school-aged children.

Encourages all schools and community centers in the United States to engage in chess programs to promote problem-solving, critical thinking, spatial awareness, and goal setting.

(This measure has not been amended since it was introduced. The summary of that version is repeated here.)

Expresses support for the designation of Saint Louis, Missouri, as the "National Chess Capital" of the United States.

Encourages the people of Saint Louis to continue promoting the educational benefits of chess among school-aged children.

Encourages all schools and community centers in the United States to engage in chess programs to promote problem-solving, critical thinking, spatial awareness, and goal setting.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
